title: What to Do If Your Kidde Carbon Monoxide Detector is Beeping

steps.title: Four beeps and a five-second pause
steps.content: Four beeps and a five-second pause This pattern indicates CO has been detected and it's an emergency . [1] X Research source Immediately evacuate all people and pets from the home, then call 911 (if there are any signs of CO poisoning) or your local fire department (if there are no CO poisoning symptoms). Read more about what to do in a carbon monoxide emergency below . Rarely, this may be a non-emergency alarm. If you have confirmed this is not a carbon monoxide emergency, you can use the Hush feature on your carbon monoxide detector to stop the beeping. Read more about this below.

steps.title: One beep or chirp every minute
steps.content: One beep or chirp every minute A regular beep every minute or so means that the battery in your carbon monoxide alarm is running low. CO detectors have batteries even if they are mounted on the wall, so they can continue to work if there's a power outage. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Two or more chirps within 30 seconds
steps.content: Two or more chirps within 30 seconds Regular rapid chirping means that your carbon monoxide detector is nearing its end of life. Kidde states that after seven years of use, their carbon monoxide detectors will start chirping every 30 seconds. [3] X Research source If you hear this sound, you likely need to replace your CO detector. If you own your own home, replace your CO detector immediately. If you rent, contact your landlord to let them know the detector is dying and you need a replacement as soon as possible.

steps.title: Random chirps or beeps
steps.content: Random chirps or beeps A loose battery or false alarms from the environment. [4] X Research source First, check to make sure the batteries in your CO detector are new and properly placed in the battery casing. If the batteries are okay, consider the following to determine if the beeping is due to environmental factors: The area around your CO detector is often humid or steamy, and may even form condensation. There's an air conditioner, heater, fan, or breezy open window near your detector. The room is consistently under 40 째F (4 째C) or over 100 째F (38 째C). If any of these are true for you, your CO detector may be in a bad spot. Try moving it to a different location. The manual that came with your carbon monoxide detector will suggest the best spots to put your detector.

steps.title: A continuous beep or squeal
steps.content: A continuous beep or squeal The unit has become unplugged or is malfunctioning. Remove the unit from the wall and make sure it's still plugged in, and ensure the batteries haven't begun corroding (which can cause this beep instead of the dead battery beep). If you can't tell why your unit is making this long beep, contact the alarm manufacturer (as well as your landlord, if you rent).

steps.title: Act quickly.
steps.content: Act quickly. If your CO alarm is making a beep that you don't understand, it's always safest to act as if it's an emergency. Never ignore a CO detector alarm .

steps.title: Evacuate the home.
steps.content: Evacuate the home. Take all people and pets in the home and go outside immediately.

steps.title: Call 911 if anyone has symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning.
steps.content: Call 911 if anyone has symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning. If anyone in your family is experiencing CO poisoning symptoms, even if they are mild, let the 911 dispatcher know immediately. [5] X Research source Carbon monoxide poisoning symptoms include headaches, weakness, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, shortness of breath, confusion, blurry vision, drowsiness, loss of muscle control, and/or loss of consciousness. [6] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Call your local fire department if there are no poisoning symptoms.
steps.content: Call your local fire department if there are no poisoning symptoms. If you call 911, the dispatcher will most likely send the fire department and an ambulance to your location, so you don't need to call the fire department separately. However, if no one in your family is showing signs of CO poisoning, you can avoid calling 911 and just contact your local fire department's non-emergency number. Once you speak to someone at the fire department, explain the situation, especially if you know the reason why your CO detector is beeping or not.

steps.title: Remain outside until the fire department clears you to return to your home.
steps.content: Remain outside until the fire department clears you to return to your home. The fire department has the tools to determine where a CO leak is coming from. Work with the fire department to figure out the next steps so you can safely return to your home. If you rent, it's also a good idea to call your landlord once everyone is safe and let them know what's going on. If you live in a building with multiple units, the issue could be more widespread than just your apartment or condo.

steps.title: Determine that the alarm is false.
steps.content: Determine that the alarm is false. Before resetting your CO detector , be completely sure that the unit isn't beeping because there's an emergency. If your unit is not beeping 4 times and then pausing and/or you've confirmed via the unit's screen that there's a non-emergency issue occurring, you can proceed with resetting it. If you aren't sure why your CO alarm is beeping, it's always safest to evacuate and call for help, even in the case of a false alarm. Try fixing the root cause of the beep before resetting it. Use this step above to determine what the cause of the beeping is (i.e. a dead battery, a dying unit, etc.). If fixing the root cause doesn't stop the beeping or the beeping isn't caused by something you can figure out (but it's not an emergency), you can continue with resetting the device.

steps.title: Press the Hush button.
steps.content: Press the Hush button. This will stop the alarm for 10 minutes, unless the smoke or debris is so bad that it's interfering with the alarm sensors. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Keep pressing the Hush button for as long as the false alarm is present.
steps.content: Keep pressing the Hush button for as long as the false alarm is present. To end the hush period early, simply press the Hush button before the hush period is over.

steps.title: Check your detector for dust and dirt.
steps.content: Check your detector for dust and dirt. If the unit is dirty or covered in dust, the sensors may be compromised and the unit may not function properly and may start throwing out false alarms. Use a duster or microfiber cloth to clean off any dirt or dust, and use a gentle stream of compressed air to get dust out of any crevices or sensors. Never use water, cleaners, or solvents. These may damage your carbon monoxide detector.

steps.title: Check the location where your CO alarm is installed.
steps.content: Check the location where your CO alarm is installed. If your detector is near air flow (such as an AC unit, heater, fan, or open window), is in a humid area, is surrounded by steam or condensation, or is near a fireplace or gas stove, your detector may be throwing false alarms due to these environmental conditions. If this is the case, move your CO detector to a location that's at least 15 feet away from any of these environmental factors, if possible.

steps.title: Ensure the unit is installed correctly.
steps.content: Ensure the unit is installed correctly. Make sure the unit is plugged in securely and is mounted properly on the wall. Also, make sure the batteries are in the right direction and the battery cover is replaced properly.

steps.title: Test your CO alarm regularly.
steps.content: Test your CO alarm regularly. To make sure your CO detector is working properly, make sure to test it once a year with canned carbon monoxide test gas. Also, be sure to test the unit's wiring at least once a month by using the Test button on the unit.
